column1:
TheBombadWeldo,"2016-11-19T22:54:32.697Z","""Ice to meet you!""","

This set is pretty darn cool! nice minifigs, a cool look, and some new parts as well! There are pretty much no play features, which is disappoiting, and i love that they parodied the Arnold Schwarzenegger version of Mr. Freeze in Batman and Robin!
Overall, a nice cheap set for starting TLBM collecters, But it could use some features.
,TRUE,4,5,5,3,5 LEGO_Ink","2016-12-01T06:03:27.87Z","When the Little Things Add Up","
column2: charset=utf-8""><meta name=ProgId content=Word.Document><meta name=Generator content=""Microsoft Word 11""><meta name=Originator content=""Microsoft Word 11""><!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">[REVIEW] The Batman Movie | 70901 Mr. Freeze Ice Attack
Set: 70901 Mr. Freeze Ice Attack

mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">As local stores are catching up in inventory, 2017 sets are already starting to hit the shelves, and LEGO stores. This recent addition comes in the form of 70901 Mr. Freeze Ice Attack. At 201 Pieces, it&#39
column2: s currently the smallest of the available sets. How does it hold up, hoping to set the stage for the upcoming film? Let&#39

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">First, we have the box art. The front of the box depicts a battle scene in a factory of sorts. The Batman Movie logo is pretty snazzy, and subtly busy, on the upper left. There are three characters included
column2: Batman, Security Guard, and Mr. Freeze. [img]https://c5.staticflickr.com/6/5561/31204407932_ee2286ecfb.jpg[/img]

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">The back of the box contains more action, with <st1:title w:st=""on"">Mr.</st1:title> <st1:sn w:st=""on"">Freeze</st1:sn> being placed into his mech, Batman enjoying a Save-the-Day beverage, SG being trapped, and the shooting feature of <st2:personname w:st=""on""><st1:title w:st=""on"">Mr.</st1:title> <st1:sn w:st=""on"">Freeze</st1:sn></st2:personname>&#39
column2: s cold cannon (which falls far from being the coolest thing about this set). [img]https://c3.staticflickr.com/6/5791/31204408362_8cd1c838a7.jpg[/img]

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">The underside of the box contains standard LEGO Legal, but also hints at a new range for LEGO Digital, called LEGO Life. Upon checking the link [LEGO.com/life], you are directed to a whimsical page geared towards [younger] fans. Yes, I'
column2: ll still download it and probably use it frequently. The LEGO Life App promo is currently exclusive to the UK, but shows a 2017 target release for the U.S. and parts of Northern Europe. More information can be found at LEGO.com/life. [img]https://c2.staticflickr.com/6/5817/30540906673_bd07e979aa.jpg[/img]
d love to think my box wasn&#39
column3: t an exception. Even though the instructions and [tiny] sticker sheet were loose-in-box, they present themselves as though they were sealed with a backer. The dimensions of the instruction booklet are more book-ish, with the staples being along what we see as the top, so when turned sideways, it holds in your hands like a small book - without the long overflaps of days past. It&#39
column4: s also similar to the box size. The 76 pages measure [as we see the image] just shy of 5&quot
column6: Long. Held in the same orientation, the box internally measures a shy 5 &frac12
column9: Long. With two bags of parts as padding, there really wasn&#39
column10: t much room for movement, and running the spine with the length of the box prevented curl under shifting bags. [img]https://c5.staticflickr.com/6/5579/31204404532_bbcaf6cdca.jpg[/img]

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">Before we move on to parts, allow me to break a barrier. There are a lot of new sets out, and we all want something exciting. Facing the obvious new elements and recolours within the <st2:stockticker w:st=""on"">CITY</st2:stockticker> theme, part of me turned and picked up this set because of the Medium Blues, and <st2:personname w:st=""on""><st1:title w:st=""on"">Mr.</st1:title> <st1:sn w:st=""on"">Freeze</st1:sn></st2:personname>&#39
column2: s head. A bigger part of me, was highly intrigued as to the fin shapes seen below the Mech Torso, and above the hips. I just couldn&#39
column3: t figure it out. Make it through the jargon and number details, and your patience will be rewarded, I promise. This set is a relative goldmine for new elements and recolours!

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">In BAG 1 you will find a wide assortment. Starting in the lower left, and moving counterclockwise:[img]https://c6.staticflickr.com/6/5528/30540904653_711c5809a0.jpg[/img]

column2: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">8x Sand Green - BRICK 1X1 W. 1 KNOB [TLG]/Brick, Modified 1 x 1 with Stud on 1 Side [BL]. This is 1 more than 2013&#39
column3: s <st2:place w:st=""on""><st2:placename w:st=""on"">Ewok</st2:placename> <st2:placetype w:st=""on"">Village</st2:placetype></st2:place>, and 1 less than 2012&#39
column4: s Haunted house. You do use all eight, but if you&#39
column5: re not concerned about a bad view from the back, you can swap the two behind the computer for a more common color.

column4: font-weight:normal"">Brick, Round 1 x 1 d. 90 Degree Elbow - No Stud - Type 2 - Axle Hole[BL]. This is the first time we are seeing this element in Red, with hopefully more to follow. The ratio is also higher, per piece, than any other set for any previous color, except the Light Bluish Gray in the Caterham, which gets 5.

column2: ve seen these before, and will get more with the upcoming Frozen sets. Still not a bad part to have, in my opinion.

column1: font-weight:normal"">1x Black Minifig, Weapon Gun, Blaster with Recessed Studs on Sides and Inside Axle Holder [BL]. These were new for 2016, and this is only the 5th set to include one.

mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">In Bag 2, the joy continues, in mostly Medium Blue! Starting in the lower left, and moving counterclockwise (Mech Body will be posted last):[img]https://c3.staticflickr.com/6/5552/31204412642_93d09fdc70.jpg[/img]

column2: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">2x Translucent Hose, Flexible Ribbed with 8mm Ends, 10L with <st2:place w:st=""on""><st2:placename w:st=""on"">Blue</st2:placename> <st2:placetype w:st=""on"">Center</st2:placetype></st2:place> Pattern [Not Yet Official]. The Element ID is #6173148. Think <st2:stockticker w:st=""on"">FLEX</st2:stockticker> HOSE 19M W/3. 18 STICK CO -INJ. [TLG]/Hose, Flexible Ribbed with 8mm Ends, 19L with <st2:place w:st=""on""><st2:placename w:st=""on"">Blue</st2:placename> <st2:placetype w:st=""on"">Center</st2:placetype></st2:place> Pattern [BL]. Again, this version is shorter, at 10L, and has slightly different linkage ends than it&#39
column3: s 19L counterpart. Those are noted in a separate picture. I really like the amount of color variation in dual moulded parts, such as these.

column2: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">1x Medium Blue Respirator and Shoulder pads[?] It holds Design #27148, and Element ID #6177648. It will more than likely be filed with all the others in Minifig, Body Wear, under the primary title of

column1: font-weight:normal"">Minifig, Armor Breastplate with Shoulder Pads[BL].

column2: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">2x Medium Blue Fists with Hole, Design #27329, Element ID #6171827. While these elements seem familiar to me, I can&#39
column3: t track them down for other inventories. They closely resemble Fists #11092
column5: font-weight:normal"">Hand Gorilla Fist[BL], but utilizing a different type of connection.

column2: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">4x Medium Blue Corner Tiles. Design #14719. FLAT TILE CORNER 1X2X2 [TLG]/
mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">5x Medium Blue FLAT TILE 1X1, ROUND [TLG]/Tile, Round 1 x 1 [BL]. These<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp
column4: s Wicked Witch and Winged Monkey Dimensions Fun Pack.

column1: 1x Dark Bluish Gray MECH Body. It holds Design #27168, and Element ID #6166882. ***As an interesting note on this element and others, the Copyright ID indicates finalization in 2015. This is yet another great indicator of the lengthy process, and previous knowledge, the LEGO Designers go through to prepare sets for the public. Whether or not it was designed specifically for this set, this element has had a lot of thought put into it, and was created to meet specifications we aren'
column4: t even know where to begin the dimensions of this part, but take a listen to the key details.

column2: >Ball socket to Ball Socket is 6L.[img]https://c2.staticflickr.com/6/5751/30540908713_7679b3f50d_m.jpg[/img]

>The previously mentioned fin detail at the bottom is the structural support that holds half of a TECHNIC Pin, allowing for a sturdy connection and a 360 degree central hip rotation.[img]https://c2.staticflickr.com/6/5458/30540904353_4335c34e06_m.jpg[/img]
>The main facade is the equivalent of 8 plates tall. Starting flush up top, working down, the bottom will lend the &frac12
column3: thickness, as indicated by the single bracket.[img]https://c5.staticflickr.com/6/5651/31204416132_2204294b65_m.jpg[/img]

column2: >The top runs flush left to right for a standard 2x4 rectangle, but runs &frac12
column3: thicker on the front. Similar to what a bracket adds outside of a structure.[img]https://c2.staticflickr.com/6/5474/30540904193_d6cc4584b0_m.jpg[/img]

column2: >Using a series of Bricks, Plates, and Brackets, it&#39
column3: s possible to support a plate at a height that is level to the top of the Ball Joint. This could come in handy for any design necessitating a concealed joint.[img]https://c4.staticflickr.com/6/5568/30540910203_c905546366_m.jpg[/img]

column2: >A few nonessential details like implied pistons and raised edges certainly add to the mechanical look, and keep it from being plain.There are also two Horizontal clips on the [implied] back.[img]https://c2.staticflickr.com/6/5612/30540908553_3bd3cdd2cb_m.jpg[/img]

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">Batman and Security Guard Minifigures . Contents for Factory Setting.
mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">Batman has a muscular front torso, and definably printed back. He&#39
column2: s also got a Utility Belt! The Security Guard also features a printed front and back. While not excessively detailed, I think the simple line around the collar, and slight sectioning of the leather belt are quite nice little details. Both characters feature dual printed faces. The guard has a stern &quot
column8: face. Both sides have a brilliant moustache printed.&nbsp

column7: scowl. In a shift away from the newer Batman sets, his cowl has moved back to tall and pointy, as was standard for The LEGO Movie. His cape is the soft, cottony fabric, instead of the more crisp canvas-like material. He gets a neat little Flame Gun [Pea Shooter] to combat the much larger freezing arsenal.[img]https://c1.staticflickr.com/6/5341/31204409992_b71d1aa818.jpg[/img][img]https://c1.staticflickr.com/6/5473/31204410712_568712614e.jpg[/img]

column1: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">The contents of bag one produce a hinged ice-block: [img]https://c3.staticflickr.com/6/5791/31204411002_a93a9efd2c_n.jpg[/img]
mso-bidi-font-weight:bold""> A well executed, yet simpler, update to Aquamans entrapment in
column4: mso-bidi-font-weight:normal""> Arctic Batman vs. Mr. Freeze: Aquaman on Ice

column3: mso-bidi-font-weight:normal""> They also produce a small factory setting: Some valves, the top of a container, a computer workstation, RED/GREEN Lever, and a hinged portion to provide some dimension.[img]https://c3.staticflickr.com/6/5815/31204411402_d7e5382bb1.jpg[/img] Two [of three] stickers are used in this process: One for the computer screen, the other is for a larger pressure gauge. Neither of them is specific to Batman, and would look great in any industrial setting. As a word of caution, the 2x2 Round Tile used for the pressure gauge has the cross pattern in back, NOT the circle. While it'
column4: s a tight fit for fingers, the best sticker application comes AFTER ensuring the tile is squarely in place, giving bearing on true top/bottom. As many have stated previously, the new elbow tubes work wonders for enhancing industrial settings, and they really give some fresh perspective to this tiny diorama. Curiously, on the back edge of the main wall, you will place a Brick, Modified 1 x 2 with Vertical Clip. It serves no direct purpose within this single set, and doesn&#39
column5: t stand in the way of any moving components, but it does serve to expand a battle scene from other sets from the movie. [img]https://c1.staticflickr.com/6/5768/30526966584_b64dd26223.jpg[/img]

column1: bold"">For now, it could also be used as the Guard&#39

column3: font-weight:normal"">Even though I never completely followed the characters, <st2:personname w:st=""on""><st1:title w:st=""on"">Mr.</st1:title> <st1:sn w:st=""on"">Freeze</st1:sn></st2:personname> has almost always been one of my favorites. Sorry <st1:sn w:st=""on"">Arnold</st1:sn>, not you. The accordion type ridges on his body armor, as well as some facial elements, are reminiscent to the character from Batman the Animated Series. However, I most particularly enjoy the individual monocle style lenses over his eyes, opposed to the goggles or sunken in appearance. His printed torso and legs are also top notch! With multiple colors of Blues, Silvers, White, and details such as hoses, a waist belt, knee pads, and boot patterns on the toes. Once the shoulder pads are in place, and the head properly on, a top-down view will show two rings that form a nice little gap that snugly grabs onto the Trans-Clear dome for his helmet. He comes with a giant freeze cannon, that contains all types of attachments. While <st2:personname w:st=""on""><st1:title w:st=""on"">Mr.</st1:title> <st1:sn w:st=""on"">Freeze</st1:sn></st2:personname> is able to us the weapon as a standing assistant, it&#39
column4: s much better suited to his Mech.[img]https://c5.staticflickr.com/6/5545/31204417412_bc1267881a.jpg[/img] [img]https://c1.staticflickr.com/6/5520/31204417672_022fc4129d.jpg[/img] [img]https://c7.staticflickr.com/6/5776/31204417862_0d651f5007.jpg[/img] [img]https://c3.staticflickr.com/6/5832/31204418082_b6eb3ca188.jpg[/img]

column3: font-weight:normal"">The Mech Body is complex, in the simple kind of<span style=""mso-spacerun:yes"">&nbsp
column4: way. Functional may be a better word. There are a massive 17 points of articulation[!!], and 11 of those have 360 capability. (An honest 9 if you don'
column5: t count the Pin and Ball socket in the wrist, twice. The friction of the socket is greater than that of the pin, so while the hand can completely rotate, the ball joint in the wrist won&#39
column6: t achieve any rotational movement, just the pin connection. A spare ball on the hip connection would allow for an 18/12 ratio, should you care to add provisional accoutrements to his rear. [img]https://c5.staticflickr.com/6/5798/30979542100_ff04471e95_z.jpg[/img]

column3: font-weight:normal"">One thing I started doing with Mixels was to search how well they balanced in odd forms. With all the articulating points, it takes time, but you&#39
column4: re not limited to simple poses. The &quot
column6: is always a good basis for extensive movement, but you can also get him to kneel. Notice you don&#39
column7: t have to have his knee touch [nor will it] to make him balance in this manner. His arms and legs are a little bare, but its certainly nothing that would deter me from picking up the set. [img]https://c2.staticflickr.com/6/5808/30540905313_662170b2b0.jpg[/img] [img]https://c8.staticflickr.com/6/5463/30540905143_8d5c3af24d.jpg[/img]

column3: font-weight:normal"">Overall, I really enjoyed the building process, and the amount of character that is packed into all the little things.
While it certainly falls into the $0.10/pc category, there is the deception of little elements. There are lots of little elements, but there are excessive new colors, and large elements, to consider.

column4: EVERYTHING MOVES! With the exception of the Guards Pistol, and turning the little flame in Batman&#39
column5: s gun, every other part of this set has some sort of moving component. There are numerous ways to change up your play process on this set.

column3: mso-bidi-font-weight:bold"">For more pictures detailing the set, as well as my other builds, head this way. Thanks for reading!

column13: > The LEGO Movie started a popular trend that has led to this. A second film and one centered on LEGO Batman, filled with great new vehicles, impressive villains and some great looking sets. Let&rsquo
column14: s start this Theme off with some fun little sets, beginning with the Mr. Freeze set.

column8: >Box: A nice little compact box with a typical fun design. The LEGO Batman Movie uses a yellow colour which complements the original LEGO Movie box design quite nicely, which originally was blue if memory serves. The logo stands out sharply in black drawing the eye and the images showcasing the set are very well executed.

>Instructions: A single manual for the two numbered bags in the set. Small in size too and quite compact enough to fit inside the box without being damaged. The back has a few pages for cross-promotional images that show other sets, the official LEGO Batman site and the DC Super Heroes Theme. A pretty impressive little manual design.
>This set has a limited number of parts. There are basic parts that are decent enough, but then you&rsquo
column9: ve got some fun new elements such as the new macaroni piece and Mr. Freeze&rsquo
column10: s battle armour torso piece, which was also introduced in the NEXO Knights theme this year. Not the best set for parts, but a good start to one.

column9: s Batman, honestly there are so many versions of this character in LEGO form discussing him seems a bit redundant, so instead of covering him regularly let&rsquo
column11: s changed compared to past versions.

column8: >He has a six-pack, or seven-pack if you prefer, carries a unique heat based weapon for dealing with Mr. Freeze and his expressions are in keeping with The LEGO Batman Movie interpretation compared to the more serious looking faces on DC Super Heroes Batmen. The new utility belt piece is just icing on the cake, after years LEGO decided to make a new piece, time will tell if they start including it in regular DC Super Hero sets though.

>Mr. Freeze: Every villain in these sets is loaded with detail, personality and charm. Mr. Freeze is no exception. He includes a lot of printed detailing for his armour with dual-sided torso printing and printing on the legs with pads and armour boots. His shoulder piece is new and attaches a dome piece over it harking back to the BtAS era fishbowl of Mr. Freeze compared to the more modern looking versions. His torso looks good enough for some extra army building for fans of the Galactic Minifigures in CMF.
>Security Guard: A generic firefighting security guard ready to prevent the villain from getting away with whatever he&rsquo
column9: s planning. Not much to say really, he&rsquo
column10: s got two expressions so he can be scared and frozen or normal and prepared for action, a standard protective gear for firefighters and a large space-style gun of some kind for pew, pew making action.

column8: >Bag 1: Batman and the Security Guard come out of this bag along with the small section of the Gotham Power Plant. There&rsquo
column9: s also an ice prison for the Security Guard. This is a pretty simple build, very fast too, compared to other sets in this price point in other Themes I fear The LEGO Batman movie sets will not meet expectations for builds. Mostly due to the small nature of the models being built, compared to larger sets this build is somewhat lacking.

column8: >Bag 2: Mr. Freeze and his Battle Armour are in this bag. This feels more solid compared to the Gotham Power Plant section. Building large armour suits are always more fun than simple set pieces that are too small for their own good. A short and simple build too very fast, both bags feature builds that are fairly simpler than sets in other Themes, not juniorized, but definitely less involved than other Themes.

column9: s Battle Suit: This is the huge draw of the set, the armoured up battle suit is a great looking model with some fun concepts and a great new piece for making battle mechs. Honestly it&rsquo
column10: s the best model in the set for me and I could definitely leave the rest of the parts for something better suited than what we&rsquo
column11: ve got. All of the baby blue parts and the overall design of this thing just impresses.

column8: >Section of Gotham Plant: This however is bland, uninspiring and just plain sad. Aside from the new macaroni parts there is very little value to be had from this model. You can&rsquo
column9: t do anything with it, there are no exploding elements, no play features of any kind and the thing is the true definition of fa&ccedil
column10: ade. The LEGO Designers should have done more than this, the jewelry store in the Catwoman set was at least a fully functional element that could be interacted with and had a bit of play value to it. Unless you buy all three of the small sets that combine the Gotham Plant together you are not getting the most for your dollar here.

column8: >I would have preferred seeing them omit the separate freeze/ice cell for the security guard and built something better suited for the set. In fact why didn&rsquo
column9: t they build a slightly larger interior build that incorporated the ice cell using the new ice prison parts from Legends of Chima? You could then have the security guard manning his post only to be suddenly trapped behind a wall of ice, and perhaps had some kind of blow-apart function. Really poor choices in execution here LEGO.

column8: >This set is a mixed bag in my opinion, the Minifigures and Mr. Freeze&rsquo
column9: s armour are really fun and impressive, but that portion of Gotham Power Plant is a bit weak, it is designed as a fa&ccedil
column10: ade and to combine with two other sets in this first wave of LEGO Batman Movie sets.

column9: d recommend this set if you plan on getting all the villains and all the sets at the same time that combine. As a stand-alone model on its own it definitely is lacking, even with the printed pieces. I find the sets in this price-range are slightly weaker compared to The LEGO Movie sets that were released at this price point. Which is a bit of a shame, however this does offer more to do than the lowest price-point set in the wave.

column1:
,TRUE,3,4,3,4,3 8BrickMario","2017-02-06T02:05:20.983Z","...darn it, Schwarzenegger took all the ice puns already.","

This set was one I went back and forth on. When I was offered a squished-box copy for 10% off, I decided to get it.

Lots of blues, greys, and some sand green, too. The ice pieces might also be desirable. The mech has some new robot fists with a stud/Technic pin attachment point, and they can hold bar-shaped pieces.
Batman- This is the standard LBM Batman, but his faces (overly angry and concentrating and cocky and confident) are both great and very "
column3: . His new utility belt is nice, and he comes with the grappling gun, here used as a flamethrower.

column1: Guard- A basic civilian in peril, who has a nice uniform with air tanks and a helmet usually used for firefighters. He has two nice faces- frustrated and terrified. He has an ACU gun extended by binoculars.

Mr. Freeze- The star of the set, and very welcome. He has a new armor piece that allows him to finally have his classic domed helmet, as it provides an adapter for the classic dome piece. I might have changed the color of the armor to something other than light blue, though. as his head blends into it. Speaking of the head, he has a new take on his classic red goggles, as they'
column2: re separate eyepieces here. He has appropriately-unhealthy cheekbones and wears a disparaging expression. The armor, as stated, makes this too much blue, so maybe they could have made his skin white instead? Either solution would work for me. Combining the body pieces with the upcoming&nbsp
column3: Juniors Freeze head might be the solution for a more classic look.&nbsp

column1: Underneath, his torso is nicely printed with his cryogenic suit, with metallic silver plating and tubing, and some joint details, plus some blue accents. My favorite detail is the ice seeping out from under the chestplate. Considering the detal on the other figures in this range, I'
column2: m slightly disappointed by the lack of arm and side-leg printing.

column1: First to be built is a hinged ice prison for the guard, but it doesn'
One of many sections of Gotham Energy features as a setpiece, but besides the coffee cup and lever, there'
column2: s really nothing to be done with it- there&#39
column3: s not even any posing room.

column2: s mech is the bulk of the set, and it&#39
column3: s a great model. The body uses a new mech-frame piece, and and the limbs are jointed nicely for the scale. I like how it&#39
column4: s a smaller piloted suit, rather than a huge mech, which are a dime a dozen for LEGO at this point. The suit is a much better wielder of Freeze&#39
column5: s huge ice gun, which has a stud-shooter on the top in an effort to create the illusion of the shots coming from the barrel. The mech has a nicely hinged back panel which encloses nicely around Freeze, and there are some blue-filled rubber hoses to create the effect of power surging through it.

column1: I have mixed feelings about this set, even for the deal I was able to get it. The mech is a good model, but Freeze himself isn&#39
column2: t my favorite of the LBM rogues, and the rest is unremarkable. If you really like Freeze, by all means, get it, but this is the kind of set that disappoints completionists.

column1:
,TRUE,4,5,4,5,5 TheBrickPal","2016-12-07T01:36:31.57Z","A chilling result","

The LEGO Batman Movie
column2: is looking to be one of the biggest new films of next year
column3: perhaps not just fueled by the&nbsp
column5: of both LEGO and DC Comics, but even by the general theater-going population and animation lovers, who found themselves impressed by&nbsp
column7: when it debuted merely three years ago.

column1: In light of this, LEGO is upping the ante with their
column3: and giving us a whopping thirteen sets in the first wave alone.&nbsp
column5: Mr. Freeze Ice Attack is the cheapest of the four-set early product launch in North America on November&nbsp
column6: 27th, and the second-cheapest of all the revealed sets for the first half of 2017.

column1: The set benefits from the fact that it can be combined with two other low-priced ones and that it has three
column6: s most famous and cold (pun intended) rogues. Plus, it contains a wonderful little&nbsp
column8: for the titular villain. But is it really full of energy like the facility it takes place in, or does it leave the theme on thin ice? Let&rsquo

column1: The first thing you see of any set before you build it is the box, and this one definitely does not disappoint and should stand out on toy shelves.
We are met with the age range of 7-12 (*The Man Upstairs voice* &ldquo
column3: s just a suggestion. They have to put that on there.&rdquo
column4: ), the piece count, name (on North American copies), and the main scene of Batman doing battle with Mr. Freeze and his&nbsp
column5: mech, in order to save a poor frozen security guard! The yellow tiled pattern of the top banner is bright and appropriate as Batman stares at us from the top right corner. It should be noted that the theme is labelled &ldquo
column7: on all of the set boxes, in order to avoid the repetition that was LEGO The LEGO Movie!

column1: The back of the box appears to depict later in the fight, with Batman able to knock Freeze&rsquo
column4: to the ground as the security guard escapes his ice prison and flees. Play features are advertised and we are encouraged to &ldquo
column6: - bringing to mind DC and Marvel Super Heroes&rsquo

column1: Inside the box are two numbered groups of plastic bags of parts, a small sticker sheet and a sixty-eight page instruction booklet. The end of the booklet shows off other TLBM sets, the LEGO minisite, and ads for DC Comics Super Heroes sets as well as an upcoming app called LEGO Life.
You must be looking for new and interesting parts in such a small set. Well, you'
column2: ll be happy to know that this set is chock-full of them...

column1: • A new style of fists with Technic holes for connection (2x)

column8: in the upcoming CMF series based on the movie. It looks simple but works fantastically. The rest of the body is a dark blue hue with light blue, grey, silver, white and black details.

column1: The three completed models are rather small
column2: as one would expect, I suppose, of a set of this size. However, all three deserve props for representing a presumably short scene in the film adequately in a cheap, physical form.

column1: The smallest and least exceptional model of them all is an ice prison for poor Mr. Guard (I will continue to call him that). It opens on a hinge and does its job well enough. I do wish the white were replaced with a blue shade
column2: preferably the shade that most of the rest of the set uses. It&#39
column3: s not really much of an issue though, and we can easily pretend it is slight frost forming at the bottom. The grey is an eyesore, though... eh, what can you do?

column1: A figure can of course be inserted on the inside studs to simulate being frozen in a block of ice. It'

The main scenery build consists of a small computer terminal wall along with a short white gas tank, piping, a valve and simulated catwalk above. We will have to wait and see whether a similar-looking scenery build will be seen at the Gotham Energy Facility in the film, but it is safe to say that this is a scaled-down, approximated version of something we will see - that is, if we see anything like it at all!
Two stickers are used in this one model
column2: the most out of the three builds. One is a meter to gauge some measurement - gas pressure, perhaps? It is placed on a black 2x2 circular tile and is complete with the initials GE (Gotham Energy) at the bottom. The other sticker showcases a monitor with some data and imagery, put on a tan 2x2 tile and stationed next to an obligatory coffee mug.

column1: To the right of that and just below the meter is a couple of 1x1 green/red lights and a simple lever in the middle. One can only wonder what this whole contraption is capable of, and whether Mr. Freeze will use it to his advantage!

A single macaroni piece sticks out from the side of the wall, leading to a classic wheel element used as a spinning valve. The entire left, non-wall section of the model is connected via a hinge - allowing for some interesting potential positions. Two more red macaroni pieces are connected here to the five-piece tank. Definitely a target for the former cryogenicist...
